content:
Quick Update. I think I found the reason.

The back-bouncing email had no message body, just a subject line. Apparently, Spam Filter automatically throws messages with no body back into Spam Box even after it's told not to, and even if the sender address appears in the Collected Address book..
creator: jl11

content:
That is usually a corrupt installation. My suggestion:

  1. exit thunderbird
  2. download the same or equivalent version from https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ (that is, if you are with ESR, stay with ESR. if with monthly, stay with monthly)
  3. although not necessary, I always encourage doing a backup prior to a fresh install.
    • ensure thunderbird is not running
    • enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
    • this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
    • highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media (or a separate folder)
  4. install the downloaded new version
creator: davidsk

content: Just to make a comment: the error message may be true. The path from your PC to the Comcast server, receiving the message being sent and also the copy to be saved. That is two transactions, and the path when sent from web server is not the same, nor is the path to Yahoo the same. So, while there may be extenuating issues, the message is sometimes true.
creator: davidsk

content:
if you think there is a corrupted install, installing a fresh download over the existing one is safe. it will use existing profile. for total safety, I suggest doing a backup anyway..

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media (or to another folder on disk)
creator: davidsk

content:
@Rick 10GB is the total for the whole box and the emails are kept locally, in addition to IMAP servers. This is an aggregate across different email accounts. Therefore, this should not affect an import. Really, it is just a matter of importing the configurations that I am concerned about. It is a pain to spend a day to do this when I prefer not to. That is why we have 'tech', to not bother with redundant tasks.

But what I guess @Rick is saying, that if you have an email inbox with a total of 10 gigs (that's all emails in aggregate), Thunderbird will no longer work as an email client. That the settings will refuse to import the email configuration at 10GB. Then Thunderbird ought to disclose that saying, "Thunderbird stores UP TO 10GB, no more!!!" Even though IMAP servers and local folders hold the email.

That is about your password for Telia.

I found some indications on the Web that Telia needs Thunderbird to use an application password. Maybe that is what you have been referring to. The application password is specific to Thunderbird but it is controlled by Telia.

If you do not have one, you may need to get one from Telia. If you have one but have forgotten it, you will need to get a new one.

content:
Jamesrsamec41 said
According to Telia, there was no problem with the code as it worked for me to get through to Telia when Telia made its test.

You said that you accessed mail at their site. Accessing mail at their site is different from accessing it from Thunderbird. Do you have an application password from Telia for Thunderbird? Do you know whether or not you need one?

Could there be some problem with the "mailin" unit of the procedure?

Yes, and other information for the incoming and outgoing server could be wrong too. You'll want to confirm with Telia that all your settings are correct. Incoming server settings are in account settings > server settings. Outgoing server settings are in account settings > click on account name > edit outoing server.

Here's what telia.com says:

Inkommande server: mailin.telia.com IMAP-port: 993 med SSL POP3-port: 995 med SSL Utgående smtp-server: mailout.telia.com Smtp-port: 465 med SSL Smtp-autentisering: På Användarnamn: Hela din mailadress Lösenord: Samma lösenord som du hade tidigare

It is still not clear to me whether or not an application password is needed.

creator: davidsk

content: My problem is that for the past year or more contents of various of my folders have turned up empty. I frequently move posts from my inbox to my folders. These same emails are automatically posted in "All Mail." This means two of the same emails/duplicates exist in various folders. I am wanting to know FOR CERTAIN if the reason my folders are turning up empty of various emails I had stored there is because I deleted the duplicate email from "All Mail"
creator: cheriek

content: Yes, that is the cause. In Gmail, there is only one real folder: Allmail. Thunderbird imitates it by duplicating all other folders. You will save roughly half your disk space, and half your internet transfer time, and much cpu resource use by unsubscribing from allmail.
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you so much for that information! Would you be so kind as to tell me how I can unsubscribe from all mail? Thank you!
creator: cheriek

content:
- highlight the account in folder pane - rightclick and select 'subscribe' - untick the box for Allmail - close and restart thunderbird

NOTE: the disk space may still be there, even though not used. if interested, you can do this after the restart: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - click the imapmail folder - click the <IMAP account folder' - if you see allmail and/or allmai.msf, just delete them - restart thunderbird </p>
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you David for taking the time to help me. I just unsubscribed from All Mail. Had no idea I could do that!
creator: cheriek

content:
Let's see if your data is still present.

Please go to "Help" (menu) > Troubleshooting information

Look down the left column of the first table until you see "Profiles". Click on "about:profiles" next to it.

The next screen will show you information about all your profiles. Identify the one that is in use. For each of the others, click on "Launch profile" and see if your data is there.

creator: davidsk

content:
These steps have worked well for many users:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there

The export/import never seems to work. but the above steps do.
creator: davidsk

content: Similar topic: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1553682
creator: sfhowes

content:
Yahoo requires a different password when using an email client and requires OAUTH2 authentication. This URL may assist: https://help.yahoo.com/kb/SLN15241.html

these are common settings: imap.mail.yahoo.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address

smtp.mail.yahoo.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address
creator: davidsk

content: Yahoo requires an app password if the authentication method is 'normal password'. This applies to many desktop and mobile mail apps that don't support OAuth2 authentication. But since TB supports Yahoo's OAuth2, use the regular account password in the OAuth window when asked for access.
creator: sfhowes
